The "family values" crowd in Texas has been searching far and wide for some research to make their support of an amendment to the Child Protective Services bill that would ban gays and bisexuals from being foster parents in Texas seem like a valiant defense of the innocence of children. There is nothing more fascinating than watching someone on the Christian Right attempt to use science to validate an argument, as though religion and science have suddenly learned to get along and stop quarreling over petty issues like the origin of life on Earth.
 
 Hallelujah! The Texas Eagle Forum has found a scientist that hates gays just as much as they do. Even better, he works for their friends at the Family Research Institute. Now all they have to do is disregard all the research that doesn't suit their needs. Not to worry, Cathie Adams is on the ball. 
 
 To arrive at the assertion that "children in same-sex couple homes are 11 times more likely to be abused sexually," Cathie Adams, of the Texas Eagle Forum, derived her numbers from two unrelated studies and mongrelized them with the findings of a researcher by the name of Paul Cameron. Cameron, of the ultraconservative Family Research Institute, had published a report that was itself a hybrid of several other studies. In it, he concluded that "homosexual practitioners were proportionately more apt to sexually abuse foster or adoptive children." 
 
 No single step that Cameron took to reach his findings is grounds for immediate dismissal of his claims. Rather, there are many small, but important, aspects of the research that, together, warrant the "junk science" label and have led many to dispute the legitimacy of his findings. The biggest logical fallacy Cameron commits is equating pedophilia with adult homosexuality by interpreting statistics that show that 34 percent of sexual abuse in foster homes is committed by a guardian of the same sex. Cameron fails to show any relationship with same-sex pedophilia and adult homosexuality, which is a crucial misstep. The assumption that every adult that touches a minor of the same sex considers him or herself a homosexual or is sexually attracted to adults of the same sex is ridiculous. Even more important is that Illinois, the state Cameron analyzed, does not keep data regarding the sexual preference of foster parents, so he was forced to use national data to reach conclusions about a study with an extremely limited scope. 
 
 When vocal activists conduct research, their conclusions will be generally dismissed as agenda-driven and unsound, especially if the methods are questionable. When Cameron's report got into the hands of Cathie Adams, who utilized fifth-grade math skills to reach her own conclusion about Cameron's findings, a study that was bad to begin with was stripped of what little merit it had left and regurgitated as propaganda. Adams' "11 times" claim contains an obviously glaring flaw. She assumes that everyone that commits sexual abuse with a minor of the same sex is in a homosexual partnership, or "household." In fact, nothing supports this assertion, and after making the unfounded claim on CNN, Adams told The Wall Street Journal, "It just requires more explanation than what you can do in sound bites." How convenient. 
 
 A far more comprehensive report, published by the American Psychological Association, analyzed the findings of a multitude of studies conducted over the last 50 years and concluded that the hysteria over same-sex foster parents is completely unfounded. The Texas Eagle Forum doesn't quote that study.
 
 It is clear that the personal belief that certain Americans lack the qualifications to raise children does not mix well with the empirical nature of science, or the U.S. Constitution. The existence of a fringe study to support an extreme viewpoint does not even come close to validating a belief. If every ridiculous attempt to scientifically prove the existence of UFOs or deny the Holocaust was taken seriously, the world would be a very different place. Luckily, the scientific community utilizes exhaustive peer-review and analytical methods to keep sub-standard research out of the overall body of knowledge. 
 
 The Texas Eagle Forum resurrected a study that failed to survive the rigors of scientific scrutiny, added their own spin, and ignored all evidence to the contrary - all to masquerade as an organization with legitimate concerns grounded in scientific data, instead of bigotry.
